Literature Review: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) has revolutionized our understanding of cancer biology by enabling the detailed examination of gene expression at the resolution of individual cells. This technology has been instrumental in uncovering the heterogeneity within tumors, elucidating the complex interactions between cancer cells and their microenvironment, and identifying potential therapeutic targets. Since its inception, scRNA-seq has been applied to a wide range of cancer types, providing insights that were previously unattainable with bulk RNA sequencing methods. The tumor microenvironment (TME), comprising various cell types including immune cells, fibroblasts, and endothelial cells, plays a crucial role in cancer progression and response to therapy. scRNA-seq has allowed researchers to dissect the TME at an unprecedented level, revealing the dynamic interactions and signaling pathways that contribute to tumorigenesis and immune evasion. For instance, studies have utilized scRNA-seq to characterize the immune landscape of tumors, identifying distinct immune cell populations and their functional states. This has significant implications for immunotherapy, as understanding the immune contexture of tumors can inform the development of more effective immunotherapeutic strategies. Moreover, scRNA-seq has been pivotal in studying the mechanisms of therapeutic resistance. By analyzing the transcriptomic profiles of individual cancer cells before and after treatment, researchers have identified subpopulations of cells that exhibit resistance to therapy, providing insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying treatment failure. Despite its transformative potential, scRNA-seq presents several computational challenges, particularly in the context of cancer research. The high dimensionality and sparsity of scRNA-seq data necessitate the development of sophisticated computational methods for data analysis. Recent advancements in bioinformatics have led to the creation of numerous tools and pipelines specifically designed for scRNA-seq data, enabling the identification of cell types, inference of cell trajectories, and detection of differentially expressed genes. However, the integration of scRNA-seq data with other omics data types, such as genomics and proteomics, remains a challenge. Additionally, the interpretation of scRNA-seq data in the context of clinical decision-making requires robust computational frameworks that can handle the complexity and variability of cancer datasets. As scRNA-seq continues to evolve, it holds great promise for advancing our understanding of cancer biology and improving patient outcomes through personalized medicine.
